class.name: Priest (Tanares)
class.proficiency: Wisdom, Charisma, History, Insight, Medicine, Persuasion, Religion

trait.name: Priest
trait.text:
Priests are simplified clerics. They are ideal for new players who are looking for less complexity or to create a more straightforward character without sacrificing effectiveness during play.
Priests are faithful servants of the gods, shining beacons of devotion who spread the word of their deity to all who will listen. Most priests serve Tamera, the radiant goddess of sun and life, while others follow Bauron, the enigmatic deity of moon and punishment. Dwarves offer their prayers to Dorsi, the god of guardianship and virtues, and among the elves, there are those who worship the Cuibhle pantheon, the gods of elements and seasons.
Acting as guides to the common people and trusted advisors to their closest allies, priests are known for their exceptional healing powers and their ability to protect those around them with sacred magic. They serve as shining lights, illuminating the path for their companions and offering hope in even the darkest of moments.
Although not trained in traditional combat, priests are equipped with the basics of armor and shield usage, allowing them to face danger with bravery. However, their true power lies in their unwavering faith and their divine magic, making them a formidable force on the battlefield and a source of inspiration to their allies. Whether ministering in small temples or venturing out into the world as adventurers, priests are a shining example of the power of the divine.
You can't multiclass into Simplified Classes, or multiclass if you are a Simplified Class.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 200 (Homebrew)

trait.name: How to play with a Priest
trait.text:
The priest class is a streamlined variation of the cleric. Unlike the clerics with their wide range of domains and vast spell options, priests specialize predominantly in support spells, geared towards healing and empowering their allies. From level one, priests wield spells capable of significantly influencing the course of a battle.
Priests are uniquely versatile, adept at functioning as both robust tanks and reliable support units. While they rely on their allies for protection, they possess access to armor and weapons for direct combat, providing a balanced role in the party. As they advance in levels, priests acquire even more potent spells, bolstering their supportive capabilities. Spells like revivify and greater restoration ensure that their comrades are perpetually ready for the fray, while offensive spells like spiritual weapon and fire storm offer a formidable attack repertoire.
Priests are deeply rooted in religious beliefs in Tanares. They serve as crucial intermediaries, shedding light on the intricate and profound topics that permeate the continent's discourse. This allows players to delve into the persona of the wise, scholarly priest, making this class a valuable asset in both combat and narrative scenarios.
In conclusion, priests offer the dual appeal of being potent allies in combat and insightful advisors outside of it. With their balance of support spells, tanking capabilities, and offensive magic, priests are an exceptional addition to any campaign. Whether you're enthralled by the concept of bestowing blessings or directly engaging in combat, priests cater to a broad spectrum of your preferences.

feature.name: Starting Priest
feature.text:
As a 1st-level Priest, you begin play with 8 + your Constitution modifier hit points.
You are proficient with the following items, in addition to any proficiencies provided by your race or background.
• Armor: Light armor, medium armor, and shields • Weapons: Simple weapons • Tools: None • Saving Throws: Wisdom, Charisma • Skills: Choose two from History, Insight, Medicine, Persuasion, and Religion
You begin play with the following equipment, in addition to any equipment provided by your background.
• (a) a mace or (b) a warhammer (if proficient) • (a) scale mail, (b) leather armor, or (c) chain mail (if proficient) • (a) a light crossbow and 20 bolts or (b) any simple weapon • (a) a priest's pack or (b) an explorer's pack • A shield and a holy symbol
If you forgo this starting equipment, as well as the items offered by your background, you start with 5d4 × 10 gp to buy your equipment.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 200 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Spellcasting
feature.text:
Due to your ability to channel divine power, you can cast spells.
Specific Cantrips: At 1st level, you know two cantrips: light and sacred flame. At 3rd level you learn an additional cantrip, spare the dying.
Simplified Spellcasting Unlike more complex classes, as a priest, your spells are predetermined by your class and you can cast each of them twice per day. Follow the Priest Spells table to know which spells you know and when you will have access to them.
Spellcasting Ability: Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for your priest spells. The power of your spells comes from your devotion to your deity. You use your Wisdom whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Wisdom modifier when setting a saving throw DC for a priest spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.
Spell save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier
Spell attack modifier = your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier
Casting spells in Higher Levels: Some spells can be cast using spell slots of a higher level, making their effects more powerful. If you have a spell that can be cast on a higher level, you can use another spell of higher level in place of it to cast that spell on a higher level. The level of the spell you spent will determine the level the spell was effectively cast.
Example: If you have cure wounds, but want to use it as a 2nd level spell, you can choose a spell of 2nd level, such as lesser restoration, to use. This counts as one of your two uses of lesser restoration, but instead of applying the effects of lesser restoration, you cast the cure wounds spell as a 2nd level spell adjusting its effects as described in it.
Spellcasting Focus: You can use a holy symbol as a spellcasting focus for your spells.
Priest Spells Table: Level | Spells 1st | bless, cure wounds 3rd | lesser restoration, spiritual weapon 5th | daylight, revivify 7th | banishment, freedom of movement 9th | greater restoration, mass cure wounds 11th | harm, heal 13th | fire storm 15th | sunburst 17th | true resurrection
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 200 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Experience
feature.text:
Your experience grants you certain practical knowledge. At 2nd level, and again when you reach 10th and 18th level, you gain proficiency in a skill of your choice.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 201 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Ability Score Improvement
feature.text:
When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 201 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Divine Cure
feature.text:
Starting at 6th level, every time you heal hit points using one of your spells, the healing is increased by +2d8 hit points. The increase in healing becomes +3d8 when you reach the 14th level in this class.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 201 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Divine Intervention
feature.text:
Starting at 20th level, you can invoke your deity to intervene on your behalf. This requires the use of an action. Describe the help you are seeking and it will occur, but the GM determines how is the nature of the intervention — the effect of any cleric spell or cleric domain spell would be appropriate. After using this ability, you cannot use it again for the next 7 days.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 201 (Homebrew)
